document.docAuthor: Camisão, Beatriz M., Cavichioli, Rodney R. & Takiya, Daniela M.
document.docTitle: Oragua copiosa Camisão, Cavichioli & Takiya, 2014, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Eight new species of Oragua Melichar, 1926 (Insecta: Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) from Amazonas State, Brazil, with description of the female terminalia of Oragua jurua Young, 1977, and new records for the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Eight new species of Oragua Melichar, 1926 (Insecta: Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) from Amazonas State, Brazil, with description of the female terminalia of Oragua jurua Young, 1977, and new records for the genus

subSubSection.paragraph: Type-locality. Comunidade Ararão/Ararinha, Rio Padauari, Barcelos, Amazonas State, Brazil .

External morphology. Head (
Fig. 5
A) with median length ranging from 0.3 to 0.6 times interocular width and from 0.2 to 0.4 times transocular width; crown with small punctuations. Ocelli (
Fig. 5
A) located on imaginary line between anterior eye angles. Antennal ledges with anterior margins vertical and slightly concave. Frons and upper portion of clypeus weakly flattened medially. Clypeus with lower portion weakly oblique in relation to frons. Epistomal suture complete. Pronotum (
Fig. 5
A) with width approximately equal to transocular width; lateral margins slightly convergent anteriorly; surface with small punctuations and weakly rugose transversally on posterior portion. Mesonotum (
Fig. 5
A) punctate and not rugose. Forewings (
Fig. 1
D) with membrane weakly delimited, including only first apical cell; with five apical cells (R 1 present); base of fourth more proximal than base of third; clavus and basal half of corium weakly punctate. Posterior legs with femoral setal formula 2 : 1 : 1 ; first tarsomere with length greater than combined length of two more distal tarsomeres; with two longitudinal regular rows of small setae on plantar surface. Other characters as in generic description.

Coloration. Body (
Fig. 1
B) brown dorsally and ventrally. Small pale maculae (yellow and white) all over the head, dorsal surface, and pleurites, which may be more elongate on forewings.

Male genitalia. Pygofer (
Fig. 5
B) without processes; weakly produced; posterior margin slightly acute; macrosetae of different sizes on apical half. Valve subtriangular (
Fig. 5
C). Subgenital plates (
Fig. 5
C) extending posteriorly to apex of pygofer; regular row of macrosetae along their extension and microsetae along lateral external margins. Styles (
Fig. 5
D) extending posteriorly beyond apex of connective; preapical lobe inconspicuous; preapical microsetae originating on ventral surface; apex acute and unciform. Connective (
Fig. 5
D) Y-shaped. Aedeagus (
Fig. 5
F) with basidorsal apodemes inconspicuous and basiventral apodemes elongate; shaft short and curved antero-dorsally. Membrane between aedeagus and anal tube with short and robust setae. Paraphyses (
Figs. 5
D, 5 E) rami separate at base (pair of paraphysis), basal connection of rami membranous; rami about four times longer than connective, with broadened apex.

Female terminalia. Abdominal sternite VII (
Figs. 5
G, 5 H) with posterior margin produced, with two lateral concavities and apex acute. Internal abdominal sternite VIII membranous (
Fig.
5
I). Valvifers I, in lateral view, (
Fig. 5
J) higher than long, with anterior margin straight and posterior margin round. Valvulae I, in ventral view, (
Fig. 5
J) with bases with outer margins produced anteriorly (
Fig. 5
K); shaft, in lateral view, with sculpturing strigate dorsally becoming concatenate towards the apex, and imbricate ventrally (
Fig. 5
L). Valvulae II, in lateral view (
Fig. 5
M), moderately broad and gradually tapered, dorsal margin broadly arcuate, with approximately 48 subtriangular teeth with denticles on anterior and posterior margins (
Fig. 5
N); apex with ventral anteapical denticles present (
Fig. 5
N).
Etymology. The specific epithet refers to the high abundance of this species in some areas sampled and wide geographical distribution.

Notes. The external color of
O. copiosa
sp. nov.
is similar to
Oragua yucarensis
, as they share the dark body with small yellow maculae on dorsal surface. However, the new species can be distinguished by the lack of a dark frons, absence of processes on the aedeagus, apex of style unciform, and paraphyses rami with broadened apices.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Oragua copiosa
sp. nov.
A–G, Male paratype. G–N, Female paratype. A, Head, pronotum, and mesonotum, dorsal view; B, Pygofer, valve, and subgenital plates, lateral view; C, Valve and subgenital plates, ventral view; D, Styles, connective, and paraphyses, dorsal view; E, Paraphyses, lateral view; F, Aedeagus and segment X of anal tube, lateral view; G, Abdominal sternite VII, ventral view; H, Abdominal sternite VII, pygofer, and gonoplac, lateral view; I, Internal abdominal sternite VIII, dorsal view; J, Valvifer I and valvula I (right), lateral view; K, Base of valvulae I, ventral view; L, Sculpturing of shaft of valvula I, lateral view; M, Valvula II (right), lateral view; N, Apex of valvula II, lateral view. Scale bars in mm.
